bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, December 22, 1875

div1.p: Reed visits New York City, where he buys Emilie Lawrence a book. He is concerned for her health.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, December 22, 1875
div1.p:
After ex-
periencing extremely cold wea-
ther for a period of a week or
more, we were, yesterday, bles-
sed with a most charming
day-- a fair sky & air just
cold enough to be invigorating-
I could not resist the tempta-
tion of visiting New York and
spending an hour or two in
sight-seeing- You must know
that Holiday week is the busiest
& gayest of all the year in
New York- The various store
windows have put on their
liveliest & brightest appearances
& the streets are over-flow-
ing with men, women & chil-
dren, hurrying to & fro, & busy in
making their Holiday purchases.
I do not think that I ever saw
Broadway toso crowded, as on yes-
terday- It seemed as if the whole
town had suddenly turned out-
Enter whatever store you
would & your progress was,
at once, arrested- You could
not move- the ladies & children
were on your right & your left-
and your whole journey was
a struggle- There were a hun-
dred beautiful presents that
I should have much liked
to have purchased for you,
my darling, but I knew that you
would not accept them-but
knowing that you would ac-
cept some little volume, I
turned my steps toward Apple-
ton's & there purchased on unas-
suming volume, which I beg that
you will accept, my darling, as
a Holiday gift, and a token of
my sincerest esteem & love.
Were I able to make it a hun-
dred fold more valuable, I
would gladly do so, and yet
I know that it would be just
as acceptable were it even
less humble. May you, my dar-
ling, spend some happy mo-
ments over its pure pages,
and as oft as you shall
openturn its leaves, think of him
who gave it-

In writing my last letter, I for-
got to say anything concerning
my solicitude in regard to
your heart- I am really afraid
that you have been more in-
disposed than your letters would
seem to intimate. Please tell
me all- Do not keep me ignorant
of the fact, if you are very sick-
I received a letter from my sis-
ter, a few days ago- She has conclu-
ded to wait till next Octr before
sending her little girls to Mur-
freesboro, and I think she has
done wisely- There are many ques-
tions that I would like to ask con-
cerning Murfreesboro, but I will
defer them till another time-
I trust, my precious E, that you
may spend as pleasant a Christ-
mas, as if is possible, under the
circumstances, & that it may be many,
many years before you shall spend
oneanother so clouded with grief-
div1.closer:
As ever, my love, your
fond & devoted Walter.
